The process consists primarily of manual activity to accomplish tasks. Production of a solicitation consists primarily of manual, paper-based steps. This requires manual compilation of information. Publication of the solicitation and communication with potential respondents is primarily via paper, in person, mail and facsimile. Publication of the solicitation may be via electronic media. Potential respondents can use telephone, facsimile, in person, e-mail, or paper as a way to keep current on any updates during the produce solicitation process. SMA focuses on meeting compliance thresholds for state and federal regulations using state-specific standards. Very little collaboration occurs with other agencies to standardize information exchange or business tasks.

levels.level_3: information. Coordination between agencies eliminates duplication of contracted services. SMA automates process to the full extent possible within the intrastate. SMA automates contract information from central location. SMA automates the process. Some in person communication remains a part of the process. SMA adopts MITA Framework, industry standards, and other nationally recognized standards for intrastate exchange of information. SMA collaborates with other intrastate agencies and entities to adopt national standards, and to develop and share reusable business services.

SMA collaborates with other interstate agencies and entities to adopt national standards, and to develop and share reusable processes including clinical information.

capability_questions.category: Business Capability Quality: Timeliness of Process
capability_questions.question: How timely is the end-to-end process?

levels.level_1: mandated requirements for timeliness (i.e., the process achieves results within the time specified by law or regulation). The process may require six (6) or more months to issue the solicitation
levels.level_2: of automation. SMA uses web portals, email distribution and Produce Solicitation tracking, for respondent communications. Timeliness exceeds legal requirements. The process completes, on average, in six (6) months or less.
levels.level_3: collaboration, use of information sharing, standards, and regional information exchange hubs. The process supports outcome oriented program management, ensures MITA compliance, and supports the shift to shared business services in both the production of solicitations and their content. The process on average requires less than three (3) months for completion.
levels.level_4: time. SMA has interstate interoperability. The process on average requires fewer than 60 business days to complete.
levels.level_5: Processes improve further through connectivity with other States and with federal agencies. Most processes execute at the point of service. Results are almost immediate.

levels.level_2: standards improve accuracy of information but the decision-making Produce Solicitation process may be erroneous or misleading. Accuracy is higher than at Level 1. capability_questions.category: Business Capability Quality: Effort to Perform; Efficiency
capability_questions.question: How efficient is the process?

levels.level_1: Process is labor intensive. There is wasted effort or expense to accomplish tasks. Process meets minimum state process guidelines and SMA performance standards. Efficiency is low.
levels.level_2: Automation and state standards increase productivity. Efficiency is higher than Level 1.
levels.level_3: SMA adopts MITA Framework, industry standards and information exchange with intrastate agencies and entities improving efficiency to 95% or higher.
levels.level_4: SMA adopts MITA Framework, industry standards and information exchange with interstate agencies and entities improving efficiency to 98% or higher.
levels.level_5: SMA adopts MITA Framework, industry standards and information exchange with national agencies and entities improving efficiency to 98% or higher.

capability_questions.category: Business Capability Quality: Data Access and Accuracy
capability_questions.question: How accurate are the results of the process?

levels.level_1: opportunity for human error. Inconsistencies and ambiguities increase the number of respondent questions and can lead to post award protests. Accuracy is low.
levels.level_2: standardized business rules definitions reduce error. SMA centralizes and coordinates contract information between Produce Solicitation agencies. The development of Medicaid specific policies and procedures for the process reduces confusion and provides accurate information within the solicitation. Accuracy improves above Level 1.
levels.level_3: standards and information exchange with intrastate agencies and entities. SMA enhances the process to support improved program management, and support the shift to shared business services in both the production of solicitations and their content. Accuracy is improved to 90% or higher.
levels.level_4: standards and information exchange with interstate agencies and entities improving accuracy to 98% or higher.
levels.level_5: standards and information exchange with national agencies and entities improving accuracy to 98% or higher.
